title: Laboratory 02
text: A researcher wondered whether a fish or cat made a better pet. He found some people who had either fish or cats as pets and measured their life satisfaction and how much they like animals. The data are saved in pets.sav.

title: Laboratory 02
text:
Q1: Frequency distribution of pet
In SPSS, the Frequency function in Descriptive Statistics provides Frequency table with bar chart by default. I‚Äôll follow this flavor in my report.
Answer



Pet
Frequency
Percentage




Cat
8
60%


Fish
12
40%


Total
20
100%



The total \(N = 20\) includes 60% of cat owners and 40% of fish owners. No missing value.
For the bar chart, see Figure¬†1
Solution

# I use function for keeping the global namespace clean. 
def freq_distb(df, col_name):
    column = df[str(col_name)]
    print('1. Frequency: ')
    freq = column.value_counts()
    print(freq)
    print('----\n2. Percentage(%): ')
    percentage = column.value_counts(normalize=True) * 100
    print(percentage)

freq_distb(pets, col_name='pet')

1. Frequency: 
pet
Fish    12
Cat      8
Name: count, dtype: int64
----
2. Percentage(%): 
pet
Fish    60.0
Cat     40.0
Name: proportion, dtype: float64



# Plotting frequency
sns.countplot(data=pets, x='pet')







Figure¬†1: Bar Chart on Frequency of pet

title: Laboratory 02
section: Q2: Life satisfaction of pet owners
text:
Q2: Life satisfaction of pet owners
Answer
Based on the box plot (Figure¬†2), life satisfaction of cat and fish owners differ in aspects below:

Median (\(Q_2\)): The box-plot shows that cat people normally have higher median of life satisfaction than the fish people.
IQR (\(Q_3 - Q_1\)): The IQR for cat people is more concentrated, while for fish people, their IQR is much wider, which indicates more variability in life satisfaction.
Range: Cat people‚Äôs life satisfaction ranges from around 50 to 70, with an outlier below 50. Fish owners‚Äô life satisfaction ranges from about 15 to 65, with an outlier below 15.

In conclusion, cat owners generally report higher and more consistent life satisfaction compared to fish owners.
Cats win! ‡∏Ö‚Ä¢Ôªå‚Ä¢‡∏Ö
Solution

# Plotting Box-plot for Cat and Fish.
sns.boxplot(pets, x='pet', y='life_satisfaction', hue='pet')
plt.show()







Figure¬†2: Life satisfaction

title: Laboratory 02
section: Q3+Q5: Histogram of life_satisfaction (+ by pet)
text:
Q3+Q5: Histogram of life_satisfaction (+ by pet)
Answer (for Question 3): The Overall Distribution (Figure¬†3)

The overall distribution shows that the highest concentration of life satisfaction is around 50.
Extremely low life satisfaction scores exist, with individuals reporting very low scores (around 10 to 30).
The peak at around 50 reflects the central tendency for both groups, but, again, the tail on the left side of this figure suggests significantly lower satisfaction exists.

Solution

sns.histplot(data=pets, x='life_satisfaction', bins=15)
plt.show







Figure¬†3: Overall distribution of life satisfaction





Answer (for Question 5): A side-by-side comparison (Figure¬†4)

For cat owners:

Life satisfaction scores are concentrated between 50 and 70, with most scores around 60.
The distribution is tight, with one outlier who has a significantly lower life satisfaction score.

For fish owners:

Life satisfaction scores are more spreading, from around 10 to 60.
The most frequent score is around 40-50, with several people having low satisfaction (below 20).
Compared to cat owners, fish owners have a wider range of life satisfaction scores.



g = sns.FacetGrid(data=pets, col='pet', hue='pet')
g = g.map(plt.hist, 'life_satisfaction', bins=15)
plt.show()







Figure¬†4: Overall distribution of life satisfaction

title: Laboratory 02
text:
Q4: Measurements to describe variables
Answer
Based on the dataset and output:



Values
Overall (pet)
Cat
Fish




Mean
46.95
60.13
38.17


Median
47.50
63.00
44.00


Standard Deviation
17.51
11.10
15.51


Range
66.00
35.00
50.00


Inter-quartile range
19.50
8.50
15.75




For central tendency: Median (\(Q_2\))

Median is a robust measure of central tendency, especially when there is a wide range of values and potential outliers. It is less affected by extreme values than the mean: providing a better representation of the typical life satisfaction for both cat and fish owners.

For dispersion: IQR (\(Q_3 - Q_1\))

IQR measures the spread of the middle 50% of the data, which is less influenced by outliers compared to the full range or standard deviation.


Solution

def get_stats(group, group_name, column):
    dict_stats = {
        'Name': group_name,
        'Mean': group[column].mean(),
        'Median': group[column].median(),
        'SD': group[column].std(),
        'Range': group[column].max() - group[column].min(),
        'IQR': stats.iqr(group[column])
    }
    return dict_stats


def describe_var():
    # Overall
    overall_stats = get_stats(pets, 
                              'Overall', 
                              'life_satisfaction')
    # Meow
    cat_stats = get_stats(pets[pets['pet'] == 'Cat'], 
                          'Cat', 
                          'life_satisfaction')
    # Fish
    fish_stats = get_stats(pets[pets['pet'] == 'Fish'], 
                           'Fish', 
                           'life_satisfaction')
    # Output as a pd.DataFrame
    df = pd.DataFrame([overall_stats, cat_stats, fish_stats])
    return df

print(describe_var())

      Name       Mean  Median         SD  Range    IQR
0  Overall  46.950000    47.5  17.506315   66.0  19.50
1      Cat  60.125000    63.0  11.102606   35.0   8.50
2     Fish  38.166667    44.0  15.508551   50.0  15.75

title: Laboratory 02
text:
Q5: Histogram by pet
See Question 3 + Question 5 (in Section 3.3).

title: Laboratory 01
text: A biologist was worried about the potential health effects of music festivals. So, one year she went to the Download Music Festival (http://www.downloadfestival.co.uk) and measured the hygiene of 810 concert goers over the three days of the festival. In theory each person was measured on each day but because it was difficult to track people down, there were some missing data on days 2 and 3. Hygiene was measured using a technique that results in a score ranging between 0 (you smell like a rotting corpse) and 5 (you smell like sweet roses). Sanitation is not always great at these places, so this researcher predicted that personal hygiene would go down dramatically over the three days of the festival. The data file is called download.sav.

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Preparation
Before working on the lab work , I started with a quick EDA.

df_download, metadata_download = pyreadstat.read_sav("./datasets/download.sav")

# A quick peek on the structure of the DataFrame. 
print('0. An overall description of this dataset: \n' + str(df_download.describe()) + '\n')
print('1. Shape - rows and columns: \n' + str(df_download.shape) + '\n') 
print('2. Variables (in SPSS) or column names: \n ' + str(df_download.columns) + '\n')
print('3. Missing values (if any): \n ' + str(df_download.isnull().sum()) + '\n')

gender         0
day_1          0
day_2        546

dtype: int64



From the output, it seems something going wrong with the column day_1. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôll check it later. Besides, the column gender should be a categorical variable rather than an int and should be corrected:

df_download['gender'] = df_download['gender'].astype('category')

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Question 1

Q1a: What do 1, 2, and 3 mean in variable ‚Äúgender‚Äù?

Answer:



Code
Label




1
Male


2

Solution:
I reached the mapping for categorical variables by accessing metadata from the given sav file by pyreadstats:

print(metadata_download.variable_value_labels)

{'gender': {1.0: 'Male', 2.0: 'Female', 3.0: 'Non-binary'}}


P.S. On another note, considering this is data from a music festival, should I assume that apart from the 90 individuals labeled themselves as ENBY, the terms ‚ÄúFemale‚Äù and ‚ÄúMale‚Äù in the dataset include both cisgender and transgender individuals?

Answer:

print(percentage)

gender

Report the result (in a formal way)
And the results of Question 1a and 1b should be reported in a formal way:
The total \(N\) for ths dataset (for the study) was 810. The sample included the following gender groups: 54.69% male, 34.20% female and 11.11% of non-binary.

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Question 2

Draw a barplot of ‚Äúgender‚Äù whose ùë¶-axis represents the percentage of each group.

Answer:
See Figure¬†1
Solution:

gender_barplot = sns.barplot(percentage)
gender_barplot.set_xticklabels(['Male', 'Female', 'Non-binary'])
plt.show()

C:\Users\Riko\AppData\Local\Temp\ipykernel_15292\2800231647.py:4: UserWarning: set_ticklabels() should only be used with a fixed number of ticks, i.e. after set_ticks() or using a FixedLocator.

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Question 3

Draw a histogram of day_1. Is there anything wrong with this variable?

Answer:
See Figure¬†2.
Solution:
From the EDA and the histogram shown below (see Figure¬†2), we can clearly identify an outlier with a ‚Äúhygiene score‚Äù significantly higher than the others. Given that the score should range between 0 and 5, this could probability be a typo or some other thing we may have overlooked.

day1_hist = sns.histplot(df_download['day_1'])
plt.show()







Figure¬†2: Distribution of Hygiene Score in Day 1






# Filter out the outlier
print(df_download[df_download['day_1'] > 5.0])

     ticket_no gender  day_1  day_2  day_3
610     4158.0    2.0  20.02   2.44    NaN


I filtered out this outlier, it‚Äôs in row number 610, and it turns out that based on the ranking, this lady was four times cleaner than the cleanest person at the music festival. Hmm‚Ä¶ 4x cleaner? Sounds like something you‚Äôd read on a box of laundry pods (see Figure¬†3). Let‚Äôs call her Ms.¬†Laundry Pod.






Figure¬†3: 4x-cleaning-power



I‚Äôm just saying this for fun (except the Ms.¬†Laundry Pod part). The hygiene score is an interval variable that we can‚Äôt simply multiply or divide the values like what I did.

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Question 4

How many cases have missing values for day_2?

Answer:
546 cases have missing values in the column day_2.
Solution:

print(df_download.isnull().sum()['day_2'])

546

title: Laboratory 01
text:
Question 5

Excluding the outlier in day 1.

Solution:
Thankfully, there‚Äôs only one outlier - Ms.¬†Laundry Pod, located at row number 610. So, for this part, I‚Äôll simply exclude that row and save the remaining data to a new DataFrame.

df_download_dropped_outlier = df_download.drop(610)
# Or I could just enter the danger zone by dropping data on the DataFrame by:  
# df_download.drop(610, inplace=True)

Also, I double checked by plotting the data once more (see Figure¬†4).

# A plot to confirm if I'm on the right track. 
df_download_dropped_outlier['day_1'].hist()







Figure¬†4: Distribution of Hygiene Score in Day 1

title: Section 02: Concepts
text:
Brief review on:

import data on SPSS
types of variable (i.e.¬†measurement) in SPSS.
SPSS syntax - a ‚Äúcode-like‚Äù thing to replicate what we have done

Research Questions and Design: showed general concepts future scholars must learn before (otherwise how could they get into the graduate school)

title: Section 02: Concepts
text:
Brief review on:

import data on SPSS
types of variable (i.e.¬†measurement) in SPSS.
SPSS syntax - a ‚Äúcode-like‚Äù thing to replicate what we have done

Research Questions and Design: showed general concepts future scholars must learn before (otherwise how could they get into the graduate school)

title: Section 02: Concepts
text:
Research Questions

Variables and causal relationships

the X-axis and Y-axis - assuming \(X\) will affect \(Y\)

\(X\) => Independent var

\(Y\) => Dependent var


are \(X\) and \(Y\) correlated or associated?
does \(X\) predict \(Y\)?
does \(X\) cause/determine/influence \(Y\)? - strong evidence needed


Confounding

associated with the \(X\) that cause or influence \(Y\)
may cause false association
e.g.¬†ice cream sales vs drowning incidents

affected by confounder - temperature - another variable makes \(X\) and \(Y\) correlated.

e.g.¬†age vs wages

age - associated with experience + wages

Controls:

Experimental
Statistical




Mediation

e.g.¬†wages - male vs female

from average wages: yes they are correlated.
but: does it imply discrimination?
look deeper: control of occupations

Simpson‚Äôs paradox

gender ‚Äìoccupation‚Äì> wages





Addressing causal inferences

Theory
Statistically related
Time: \(X\) happens earlier
The causal inferences: proof no rival explanations for the changes of \(Y\).

(Brannon et al., 2017; Cozby & Bates, 2017)

title: Section 02: Concepts
text:
Research Design

Experiment

grouping and control
control group vs treatment group
randomized, standardized, clear-defined dependent variable
RCT - Randomized controlled trial: cost, ethic, external validity



Non-experiment

correlational research: e.g.¬†questionnaires
cost: generally **doesn‚Äôt lead to causality‚Äù

temporal precedence + confounding
correlations \(\neq\) causation




Quasi-experiment

use pre-existing groups - Nonequivalent control group

e.g.¬†free lunch in school 1 but not in school 2
confounding my exists

use data before and after the intervention - One-group pretest-post-test design

e.g.¬†maturation




Comparison of designs

internal validity vs external validity
trade-offs

title: Section 02: Concepts
text: Populations and Samples

title:
Lecture Notes / Assignments
on EDUC8009
text:
„Çà„ÅÜ„Åì„Åù!
This is my personal repository for datasets, lecture notes & assignment submissions on EDUC8009 - DESCRIPTIVE AND INFERENTIAL STATISTICS.
As this course is tailored for SPSS users, here‚Äôs the problem: I can only get my hands on the legal copy in our computer lab, where the machines are about as speedy as a sloth on a lazy day, sporting a single-channel 8GB of RAM. Apple may claim that 8 is enough (even greater than 16) for most users, and we all know that‚Äôs just some optimistic marketing.
So, I decided to take a detour and embrace the open-source revolution with sweety sidekick: python=3.10 armed with the duo of Doolin and Dal‚Ä¶, sorry, pandas and scipy.stats. An R=4.3.3 implementation will also be included in the solution of my assignment as well.



It all starts from iris and mtcars.


Riko

title: Session 01: Introduction
text:
We didn‚Äôt discuss too much on statistics or quantitative methods.
Rather, we tried to import dataset into SPSS and played around with datasets below:

mtcars: a built-in dataset in base-r, wrapped in an .xlsx file for some reason.
temphr10.sav: a dataset came from the textbook, looks like a series of weather data.

title: Session 01: Introduction
text:
We didn‚Äôt discuss too much on statistics or quantitative methods.
Rather, we tried to import dataset into SPSS and played around with datasets below:

mtcars: a built-in dataset in base-r, wrapped in an .xlsx file for some reason.
temphr10.sav: a dataset came from the textbook, looks like a series of weather data.

title: Session 01: Introduction
text:
Implementations
Since I use python for my daily work, the data were loaded to pandas.

# Also, for descriptive statistics, pandas itself is enough for the job. 
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns


# Load the SPSS dataset called "temphr10.sav".
temphr10 = pd.read_spss('./datasets/temphr10.sav')
# I converted the excel file to csv. 
mtcars = pd.read_csv('./datasets/mtcars.csv')


In SPSS: Measures of variables

# What's in the variable view in SPSS
temphr10.columns

Index(['sex', 'hr', 'temp_Fahrenheit', 'temp_Celcius', 'Likert_rating'], dtype='object')


In SPSS: - Nominal: labels, e.g.¬†races or gender / sex - Ordinal: ranking - Interval: ordinal, equally spaced, e.g.¬†temperature, IQ - Ratio: interval + a true zero point, e.g.¬†ago, wage, height, weight (it can be 0)







Level of Measurement
Valid Operations




Nominal
\(=\), \(\neq\)


Ordinal
\(=\), \(\neq\), \(<\), \(>\)


Interval
\(=\), \(\neq\), \(<\), \(>\), \(+\), \(-\)


Ratio
\(=\), \(\neq\), \(<\), \(>\), \(+\), \(-\), \(\times\), \(\div\)

title: Laboratory 01 (feat. R)
text:
What do 1, 2, and 3 mean in variable ‚Äúgender‚Äù? What are their percentages in the sample?
Draw a barplot of ‚Äúgender‚Äù whose ùë¶-axis represents the percentage of each group.
Draw a histogram of ‚Äúday_1‚Äù. Is there anything wrong with this variable?
How many cases have missing values for ‚Äúday_2‚Äù?
(Extra credit) Exclude the outlier.

base-r version 4.3.3

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)


Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union



# Using `foreign` is truly a pain for handling SPSS data, I'll use heaven instead. 
download_festival <- haven::read_sav('./datasets/download.sav')

Draw a barplot of gender whose \(y\)-axis represents the percentage of each group.

title: Laboratory 01 (feat. R)
text:
What do 1, 2, and 3 mean in variable ‚Äúgender‚Äù?

  attr('labels')

         1          2          3

title: Laboratory 01 (feat. R)
text:
What are their percentages in the sample?


print('Q1b: What are their percentages in the sample?')

[1] "Q1b: What are their percentages in the sample?"

gender_percentage <- download_festival %>%
  group_by(gender) %>%
  summarise(Percentage = n() / nrow(download_festival) * 100)
print(gender_percentage)

# A tibble: 3 √ó 2
  gender         Percentage
  <dbl+lbl>           <dbl>
1 1 [Male]             34.2
2 2 [Female]           54.7
3 3 [Non-binary]       11.1

title: Laboratory 01 (feat. R)
text:
Draw a barplot of gender whose \(y\)-axis represents the percentage of each group.


download_festival$gender <- factor(download_festival$gender, levels = c(1,2,3), labels = c('Male', 'Female', 'Non-binary'))

ggplot(download_festival, aes(x=gender)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  xlab('Gender') + 
  ylab('Percentage') + 
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) + 
  ggtitle('Percentage of Gender')

title: Laboratory 01 (feat. R)
text:
Exclude the outlier.


print('Exclude Ms. Laundry Pod.')

[1] "Exclude Ms. Laundry Pod."

download_festival_no_outliers <- download_festival[download_festival$day_1 <= 5, ]
ggplot(download_festival_no_outliers, aes(x=day_1)) + 
  geom_histogram(color = 1, bins=15) + 
  labs(title='Histogram of Hygiene Scores on the 1st Day', 
        subtitle='Outlier removed') + 
  xlab('Day 1') + 
  ylab('Frequency / Count')

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
preliminary data screening
choosing appropriate descriptive statistics based on data distribution
thoroughly reporting statistical findings, e.g.:

data cleaning
outlier handling procedures

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
preliminary data screening
choosing appropriate descriptive statistics based on data distribution
thoroughly reporting statistical findings, e.g.:

data cleaning
outlier handling procedures

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Why doing descriptive statistics?
Screening:
- missing data - unusually values - too small groups - mistakes - e.g.¬†impossible values
Then: correct them or drop them

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Frequency Distributions

Used for preliminary data screening
Frequency tables for categorical variables
Histograms for continuous variables


import pandas as pd
from scipy import stats
import seaborn as sns


temphr10 = pd.read_spss('./datasets/temphr10.sav')
temphr10.columns

Index(['sex', 'hr', 'temp_Fahrenheit', 'temp_Celcius', 'Likert_rating'], dtype='object')



# Frequency Tables for Categorical Variables (slides p.6)
temphr10['sex'].value_counts()

sex
Male      7
Female    3
Name: count, dtype: int64



# Filtering missing data with haircolor dataset (p. 6)
haircolor = pd.read_spss('./datasets/haircolor.sav')
haircolor.columns

Index(['casenumber', 'haircolor', 'newgrouphaircolor'], dtype='object')



# To count missing value, use sum() and isnull(). 
haircolor.isnull().sum()

casenumber           0
haircolor            4
newgrouphaircolor    5
dtype: int64





casenumber           0
haircolor            4
newgrouphaircolor    5
dtype: int64



The total \(N\) for the study was 50. The sample included these hair color groups: 32% brown, 24% black, 16% blond, 6% red, 6% gray, 4% pink, 2% blue, 2% out‚Äêof‚Äêrange scores, and 8% missing values.

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Central Tendency Measures

Mode: Most frequent value
Median: Middle value
Mean: \[M = \bar{X} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N X_i}{N}\]

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Variability/Dispersion Measures

Range: Max - Min
Interquartile Range (IQR): Q3 - Q1
Variance: \[s^2 = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N (X_i - M)^2}{N - 1}\]
Standard Deviation: \[s = \sqrt{s^2}\]


# BMI dataset and the boxplot
bmi = pd.read_spss('./datasets/bmi.sav')
bmi.columns

Index(['idnumber', 'Sex', 'Weight', 'height', 'BMI'], dtype='object')



sns.boxplot(data=bmi, x='Sex', y='BMI')

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Z-scores
\[z = \frac{X - M}{SD}\]

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
5. Normal Distribution

Bell-shaped curve
68-95-99.7 rule for standard deviations

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
6. Skewness and Kurtosis

Measures of distribution shape
Skewness: \[\frac{1}{N} \sum(\frac{X - M}{SD})^3\]
Kurtosis: \[\frac{1}{N} \sum(\frac{X - M}{SD})^4\]

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
7. Assessing Normality

Histograms with normal curve
Q-Q plots

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
8. Outliers

Often defined as |z| > 3.29

title: Session 03: Descriptive Statistics
text:
9. Reporting Descriptive Statistics

Include sample size, measures of central tendency, and dispersion
Describe distribution shape and presence of outliers
Use appropriate visualizations (histograms, boxplots)
